Comment: In reply to the king's pawn opening, black plays the Sicilian defence.
In reply to the king's pawn opening, black plays the Sicilian defence.
Although not so powerful (as I learned later), white plays the Morra gambit.
Black accepts the gambit.
Black accepts the gambit.
Black accepts the gambit.
White sacrifices a pawn but gains control of the centre and develops attack opportunities.
A form of Siberian variation is played, which could later develop in the famous "Siberian Trap" (where black captures white's queen), but otherwise still with potentially a better game for black.

Black pins the knight, but does not threaten anything significantly (a Bxc3 exchange would leave black's knight in c6 with even less mobility).
White naturally castle and the knight is free to move.
Black reckons it's time to castle as well, though Ne7 leaves the knight with few options to further develop.
White pre-empts a possible Qb6 development.
As expected, castling.
White begins to harass.
Preventing white's Bc5 attack.

White brings the queen into the game and contemplates a potential attack on king's side.
Black needs to start developing the game, but does not have too many options.
White aims to exchange queens, while capturing a pawn and leaving the rook in an uncomfortable setting for black.
Black defends the weak pawn, but has wasted a move.
Pushing the pawn to increase the pressure, while opening the white diagonal for the queen, in view of a deadly attack.
Black has to block and the knight move is his best option. (Pushing the f7 pawn would have weaken the defence of the king).
But that's exactly what white wants, thus attacking the queen.
Black secures the queen while seeking to annihilate white's offensive by capturing the pawn in e5. NB. white's bishop remains problematic.
